s.gd: Aig an àm, 1956, ’s e rùn-dìomhair stàite a bha san eachdraidh seo.
s.en: At the time, 1956, this story was a state secret.

s.gd: ’S dòcha gur e sin a tha innte fhathast, ach mas e, tha mi cinnteach nach aidich an Riaghaltas gun thachair càil dhen t-seòrsa.
s.en: Perhaps it still is that, but if so, I am sure that the Government will not admit that anything of the kind happened.

s.gd: Canaidh iad gur e uirsgeul a tha ann no gur e fealla-dhà a tha air m’ aire.
s.en: They will say that it is a legend or that my memory is confused.

s.gd: Tha mi a’ faireachdainn saor an aithisg a sgrìobhadh a-nis, oir cha ghoirtich i duine: bhàsaich peathraichean a’ Chòirneil, Anna agus Peigi, o chionn fhada.
s.en: I feel free to write the report now, because it will not harm anybody: the Colonel’s sisters, Anna and Peggy, died a long time ago.

s.gd: Duine gun lochd a bh’ ann an Coinneach Mhurchaidh ’ain Sheumais.
s.en: Kenneth Murdo John James was a man withour flaws.

s.gd: ’S e an Còirneal a bhiodh aig beag is mòr air, agus ’s e sin a bha e fhèin ag iarraidh ged nach robh e a-riamh ann an arm.
s.en: Everyone, meek or mightly, called him the Colonel, and that is what he himself wanted even though he had never been in an army.

s.gd: Bhiodh duine còmhla ris greis mhath mus aithnicheadh e gu robh laigse inntinn air, oir ’s e duine mòr làidir a bh’ ann, le guth pongail agus aghaidh chruaidh, dhuineil, a bhiodh freagarrach air seanailear sam bith.
s.en: A person would be with him for a good while before he would realise that he had a mental weakness, becaude he was a big strong man with an eloquent voice and a hard manly face which would be appropriate for any general.

s.gd: Ach ’s dòcha gun canadh an coigreach, “Nach ann againn a tha an teas an-dràsta,” agus fhreagradh an Còirneal, “Seo an seòrsa là a bh’ ann nuair a thuirt an ‘Auk’ rium gum b’ fheàirrde mi drama,” agus dh’innseadh e mar a chaidh a leòn sa chogadh agus mar a thàinig Sir Claude Auchinlech dhan ospadal a choimhead air.
s.en: But perhaps the stranger would say, “Don’t we have heat now,” and the Colonel would reply, “This is the kind of day it was when the ‘Auk’ said to me that a dram would do me good,” and he would tell how he was injured in the war and how Sir Claude Auchinlech came to the hospital to see him.

s.gd: Chailleadh e an uair sin a ghrèim air an fhìrinn agus bhiodh e ann an saoghal dha fhèin, saoghal anns an robh e na chòirneal.
s.en: He would then lose his grip on the truth and he would be in his own world, a world in which he was a colonel.

s.gd: Bha tinneas nan alt air a dhèanamh cuagach agus bha e a’ creidsinn gur e leòn cogaidh a bha seo, agus gur e peinnsean-cogaidh a bha san airgead a bha e a’ faighinn bhon Riaghaltas.
s.en: A disease of the joints had made him lame and he believed that this was a war injury, and that the money that he got from the government was a war pension.

s.gd: Nuair a thill mi dhachaigh an dèidh a bhith fichead bliadhna san RAF, chuir e fios orm agus shuidhich e mi mar cheannard air an sguad a bha a’ dol [TD 17] ga adhlacadh ‘le làn-onairean cogaidh’ nuair a thigeadh an t-àm.
s.en: When I returned home after being in the RAF foe twenty years, he send for me and he appointed me the chairman of the squad that was going to bury him ‘with full military honours’ when the time came.

s.gd: Bha e air bhoil mu arm is cogadh, ’s bha mion-eòlas aige air a h-uile blàr bho linn nan creach.
s.en: He was obsessed with army and war, and he had detailed knowledge of every battle from the Age of Forays.

s.gd: Dh’innseadh e dhomh na mearachdan a rinn a h-uile ceannard ann an eachdraidh na rìoghachd, na bheachd-san co-dhiù.
s.en: He would tell me the mistakes that every chief in the history of the kingdom had made, in his opinion anyway.

s.gd: Nuair a dh’fhàgadh an t-amaideas sin e bha e geur air a theanga.
s.en: When that foolishness left him he had a sharp tongue.

s.gd: ’S tric a bhios daoine a’ bruidhinn air na rudan èibhinn no eirmseach a thuirt e, ged tha fios gun deach iomadh facal a chur na bheul nach tuirt e idir.
s.en: People often speak of the funny or witty things that he said, even though it is known that many a word was put in his mouth that he didn’t say at all.

s.gd: Chuala mi e ag ràdh uair is uair rud a thug gàire orm.
s.en: I heard him saying time and again somthing which made me smile.

s.gd: Rinn Peigi, a phiuthar, teatha dhomh aon fheasgar agus thuirt i: “Cha dèan mi coigreach dhìot.
s.en: Peggy, his sister, made me tea one evening and she said: “I won’t make a stranger of you.

s.gd: Cha leig mi leas na soithichean spaideil a thoirt a-mach.”
s.en: I won’t bother taking out the fancy crockery.”

s.gd: “’S duilich dhut,” ars an Còirneal, “chan eil iad agad.”
s.en: “That is difficult for you,” said the Colonel, “you don’t have any.”

s.gd: Bha mi là eile a’ rùsgadh poll-mònach còmhla ris nuair a stad luchd-turais a chòmhradh rinn.
s.en: Another day I was cutting peat with him when some tourists stopped to talk to us.

s.gd: “Tha ’n t-àite seo coimhead glè fhallain,” arsa nighean.
s.en: “This place looks very healthy,” said a girl.

s.gd: “Cha bhi daoine a’ bàsachadh an seo glè thric.”
s.en: “People don’t die here very often.”

s.gd: “Cha bhi duine a’ bàsachadh an seo ach aon uair,” arsa mo charaid cho sòlaimte ri èildear.
s.en: “Someone only died here once,” said my friend as solemn as an elder.

s.gd: Bha nàbaidh dhuinn a’ dol dhan bhaile mhòr gu agallamh airson obair agus dh’iarr e comhairle air.
s.en: A neighbour or ours was going to the city for an interview for a job and he asked him for advice.

s.gd: “Ge bith dè na nì thu de chòmhradh,” ars an Còirneal, “na can càil.”
s.en: “No matter what you do for conversation,” said the Colonel, “don’t say anything.”

s.gd: Cha robh duine sa chlachan an uair ud nach innseadh sgeulachd mu dheidhinn rud a thuirt an Còirneal ris, ach ’s i an tè as fheàrr leam fhìn an rud a thuirt e nuair a thàinig an dà cheannaiche a bha sa bhaile dhan taigh againn agus a shuidh iad, duine air gach taobh dheth.
s.en: There was not a person in the village at that time who would not tell a story about something the Colonel had said to them, but the one that I prefer myself was the thing that he said when the two shopkeepers in the town came to our house and they sat down, one on either side of him.

s.gd: “Abair gu bheil thu dòigheil a-nis,” arsa m’ athair.
s.en: “How fine you are now,” said my father.

s.gd: “Tha mi dìreach mar a bha an Slànaighear,” arsa mo charaid, “eadar dà ghadaich.”
s.en: “I am just like the Saviour was,” my friend said, “between two thieves.”

s.gd: Bha e ceithir fichead bliadhna a dh’aois nuair a dh’fhàs e tinn le aillse na chom, agus rinn sin an clachan tùrsach.
s.en: He was eighty years old when he fell ill with bowel cancer, and that made the village sorrowful.

s.gd: Chaidh a thoirt a Ghlaschu dhan ospadal.
s.en: He was taken to Glasgow to the hospital.

s.gd: Bha Peigi agus Anna na b’ aosta na e fhèin, ’s cha b’ urrainn dhaibh a dhol còmhla ris.
s.en: Peggy and Anna where older than he himself, and they were not able to go with him.

s.gd: Dh’iarr iad orm a chùram a ghabhail agus rinn mi sin.
s.en: They asked me to look after him and I did that.

s.gd: Bha mi a’ dol ga choimhead a h-uile madainn ’s a h-uile feasgar, ach cha robh guth aige air càil ach a bhith air adhlacadh le làn-onairean cogaidh.
s.en: I went to see him every morning and every evening, but he could only talk about being buried with full military honours.

s.gd: Thàinig ambalans le Seanailear Shytonyu aon mhadainn agus chunnaic mi e.
s.en: One morning an ambulance arrived with General Shytonyu and I saw him.

s.gd: B’ e an t-uachdaran a bh’ air Dyger, an Afraga, aig an àm, agus bha e ainmeil airson a bhrùidealachd.
s.en: He was the leader of Dyger, in Africa, at the time, and he was famous for his brutality.

s.gd: An ath là bha na pàipearan-naidheachd ag innse mu dheidhinn na tubaist rathaid san robh e air a dhroch leòn.
s.en: The next day the newspapers were telling about the road accident in which he had been badly injured.

s.gd: Màsasmo a bha na cheannard roimhe gus na ruahag esan e.
s.en: Masasma who had been the chief before until he had bansihed him.

s.gd: Sheall mi na pàipearan don Chòirneal.
s.en: I showed the papers to the Colonel.

s.gd: “Chan eil rùm do dh’aon rioban eile air na broillichean sin,” arsa mise.
s.en: “There is no room for another ribbon on that chest,” I said.

s.gd: “Tha gu leòr rum air am mionaichean,” ars esan.
s.en: “There is plenty of room on their bellies,” he said.

s.gd: ’S e daoine mòra reamhar a bh’ annta ach cha do leugh e mun deidhinn idir.
s.en: They were big fat men but he did not read about them at all.

s.gd: Bha boil ùr a’ dèanamh dragh dha.
s.en: A new obsession was troubling him.

s.gd: “Tha thìde a bhith a’ smaoineachadh air na facail ainmeil mu dheireadh a chanas mi,” ars esan.
s.en: “It is time to think about the famous last words that I will say,” he said.

s.gd: Dh’innis mi dha an rud a thuirt Burns: ‘Na leig leis a’ sguad leibideach losgadh aig m’ uaigh’.
s.en: I told him the thing that Burns said: ‘Don’t let the awkward squad fire at my grave’.

s.gd: Thàinig fiamh a’ ghàire air aghaidh.
s.en: The hint of a smile came on his face.

s.gd: Chan fhaca mi e a-riamh a’ dèanamh gàire ceart.
s.en: I had never seen him smile properly.

s.gd: Thòisich e an uair sin ag innse dhomh nam facal deireannach air an robh e a’ beachdachadh.
s.en: He then started telling me the last words that he was considering.

s.gd: Ach mu dheireadh roghnaich e: “Gualainn ri gualainn gu buaidh no gu bàs,” agus dh’iarr e orm an sgrìobhadh sìos.
s.en: But finally he decided: “Shoulder to shoulder to victory or to death,” and he asked me the write them down.

s.gd: Cha b’ urrainn dha na dotairean càil a dhèanamh dha agus dh’innis iad dhomh nach robh a’ chrìoch fad’ às.
s.en: The doctors were not able to do anything for him and they told me that the end was not far off.

s.gd: Tha fios gu bheil mearachdan a’ tachairt sa h-uile ospadal.
s.en: It is known that mistakes happen in every hospital.

s.gd: Chuala mi dotair ag ràdh nach robh e a’ toirt do charaid dhomh ach sia mìosan eile, ach bha an duine beò deich bliadhna an dèidh sin.
s.en: I heard a doctor saying that he was only giving a friend of mine six more months, but the man was alive ten years after that.

s.gd: Leugh mi mu dheidhinn bean-phòsta a thàinig dhachaigh à ospadal leis an leanabh cheàrr, agus mu lannsair a thug sùil às an duine cheàrr.
s.en: I read about a wife who came home from hospital with the wrong baby, and about a surgeon who removed an eye from the wrong man.

s.gd: Gun teagamh, cha do thachair rud cho dona ri sin dhan Chòirneal, ach tha mi cinnteach gun aontaich sibh gu robh an rud a thachair dha dona gu leòr.
s.en: Without doubt, nothing as bad as that happened to the Colonel, but I am sure that you will agree that the thing that happened to him was bad enough.

s.gd: Bhàsaich e às a chadal, agus ’s ann an dèidh sin a chaidh a’ mhearachd a dhèanamh.
s.en: He died in his sleep, and it was after that that the mistake was made.

s.gd: Rinn mise ullachadh airson an dust a thoirt dhachaigh.
s.en: I made preparation for taking the body home.

s.gd: Chaidh a’ chiste-laighe a chur air bòrd anns a’ chùlaist, agus mar a bha - agus a tha - san fhasan, dh’fhosgail mi a’ chiste gus am faiceadh na càirdean an Còirneal.
s.en: The coffin was put on a table in the back, and as it was – and is – the fashion, I opened the chest so that the friends would see the Colonel.

s.gd: Bha e soilleir sa bhad gun deach mearachd mhòr a dhèanamh ann am marbhlann an ospadail.
s.en: It was clear immediately that a big mistake had been made in the hospital mortuary.

s.gd: ’S e duine dubh a bha sa chiste!
s.en: It was a black man that was in the coffin!

s.gd: Cha tigeadh duine dhan taigh-fhaire gu beul na h-oidhche.
s.en: Nobody would come to the wake until nightbreak.

s.gd: Bha tìde gu leòr agam airson smaoineachadh.
s.en: I had plenty of time for thinking.

s.gd: Thuig mi sa bhad gu feumainn fios a chur gu Oifis nan Cèin-Thìrean.
s.en: I understood immediately that I would need to send a message to the Foreign Office.

s.gd: Dhùin mi a’ chiste agus chaidh mi dhan taigh againn fhìn far an robh fòn san rùm agam.
s.en: I closed the coffin and I went to my own house where a telephone was in my room.

s.gd: Gu fortanach dhòmhsa, bha mi eòlach air Group Captain Gus Trevor-Ròper bho àm a’ chogaidh agus bha e a-nis le àrd-inbhe ann an Oifis nan Cèin-Thìrean.
s.en: Fortunately for me, I knew Group Captain Gus Trevor-Roper from the time of the war and he was now high up in the Foreign Office.

s.gd: “Carson a dh’fhosgail thu a’ chiste?” ars esan.
s.en: “Why did you open the coffin?” he said.

s.gd: Dh’innis mi dha mun chleachdadh a bha againn.
s.en: I told him about the custom that we had.

s.gd: “Tha e fortanach nach eil an cleachdadh sin an Dyger,” ars esan.
s.en: “It is fortunate that that custom is not in Dyger,” he said.

s.gd: “Chaidh do charaid a thiodhlaiceadh a’ bhòn-dè le làn-onairean cogaidh.
s.en: “Your friend was buried the day before yesterday with full military honours.

s.gd: Feumaidh sinn seo a ghleidheadh againn fhìn.
s.en: We must keep this to ourselves.

s.gd: Tha Seanailear Màsasmo a-nis a’ riaghladh Dyger agus a’ dol a thoirt dhuinn cùmhnant luachmhor airson armachd.
s.en: General Masasmo is now ruling Dyger and is going to give us a valuable contract for armaments.

s.gd: ’S ann bho Ruisia a bha Shytonyu a’ ceannach a h-uile càil dhen t-seòrsa.
s.en: It was from Russia that Shytonyu bought everything of the sort.

s.gd: Tha mi ag innse seo dhut gus an tuig thu cho cudromach ’s a tha e seo a chumail dìomhair.
s.en: I am telling you this so that you understand how important it is to keep this secret.

s.gd: Tha e glè fhurasta Màsasmo a chur troimh-chèile, agus ’s ann òirnne a chuireadh e a’ choire.
s.en: It is very easy to confuse Masasmo, and it is us that he would blame.

s.gd: Cuir clàr air a’ chiste gus nach fhaod duine a fosgladh, ’s gabh air adhart leis an adhlacadh mar as àbhaist.
s.en: Put a board on the coffin so that nobody can open it, and proceed with the funeral as normal.

s.gd: ’S cinnteach nach eil diofar càit an tèid corp a chur fon talamh?”
s.en: Surely there is no difference where a body is put under the ground?”
